title: Matrices
description: Learn about matrix definitions, types, operations, transpose, and properties of matrices.

content.text: A matrix is an ordered rectangular array of numbers or functions. The numbers or functions are called the elements or entries of the matrix.
A matrix having m rows and n columns is called a matrix of order m×n.
There are several special types of matrices based on their structure and elements:

items: Row Matrix: Matrix with only one row
Column Matrix: Matrix with only one column
Square Matrix: Matrix with equal number of rows and columns
Diagonal Matrix: Square matrix where all non-diagonal elements are zero
Scalar Matrix: Diagonal matrix where all diagonal elements are equal
Identity Matrix: Scalar matrix where all diagonal elements are 1
Zero Matrix: Matrix where all elements are zero
Symmetric Matrix: Square matrix that is equal to its transpose (A = Aᵀ)
Skew-Symmetric Matrix: Square matrix that is equal to the negative of its transpose (A = -Aᵀ)

content.text: Matrices can be added, subtracted, and multiplied under certain conditions. These operations follow specific rules and properties.

items: Matrices must have the same order to be added or subtracted
Addition is performed element-wise: (A + B)ᵢⱼ = Aᵢⱼ + Bᵢⱼ
Matrix addition is commutative: A + B = B + A
Matrix addition is associative: (A + B) + C = A + (B + C)
A matrix can be multiplied by a scalar (number): (kA)ᵢⱼ = k(Aᵢⱼ)
k(A + B) = kA + kB
k(lA) = (kl)A
Product AB is defined if the number of columns in A equals the number of rows in B
If A is m×n and B is n×p, then AB is m×p
Matrix multiplication is not commutative: AB ≠ BA in general
Matrix multiplication is associative: (AB)C = A(BC)
(A + B)C = AC + BC and A(B + C) = AB + AC (distributive property)

content.text: The transpose of a matrix A, denoted by Aᵀ, is obtained by interchanging its rows and columns.
If A = [aᵢⱼ] is an m×n matrix, then Aᵀ = [aⱼᵢ] is an n×m matrix.

items: (Aᵀ)ᵀ = A
(A + B)ᵀ = Aᵀ + Bᵀ
(kA)ᵀ = kAᵀ (where k is a scalar)
(AB)ᵀ = BᵀAᵀ

content.text: These special types of square matrices have important properties and applications.

items: A square matrix A is symmetric if A = Aᵀ
Elements symmetric about the main diagonal are equal: aᵢⱼ = aⱼᵢ
For any square matrix A, A + Aᵀ is symmetric
A square matrix A is skew-symmetric if A = -Aᵀ
All diagonal elements of a skew-symmetric matrix are zero
For any square matrix A, A - Aᵀ is skew-symmetric

questions.text: Order of matrix with 3 rows, 4 cols?
questions.explanation: A matrix with m rows and n columns has order m×n, so 3 rows and 4 columns give order 3×4.
The transpose interchanges rows and columns. Row 1 becomes column 1, and row 2 becomes column 2.

questions.text: Always true for square matrix A?
questions.explanation: (A+Aᵀ)ᵀ = Aᵀ+(Aᵀ)ᵀ = Aᵀ+A = A+Aᵀ, so A+Aᵀ is symmetric.

questions.text: If A is 2×3, B is 3×4, order of AB?
questions.explanation: For matrix multiplication, the number of columns in the first matrix must equal the number of rows in the second. The result has the same number of rows as the first matrix and the same number of columns as the second matrix.

If A is skew-symmetric, then A = -Aᵀ. Taking transpose of both sides: Aᵀ = (-Aᵀ)ᵀ = -A.
This matrix has 1s on the diagonal and 0s elsewhere, making it both an identity matrix and a diagonal matrix.

questions.text: Matrix with all zeros is called?
questions.explanation: A matrix where all elements are zero is called a null matrix or zero matrix.
